awd_titl_txt: CC* Team:  KyRC - A Kentucky Research Computing Team
awd_abstract_narration:
High performance computing centers now serve a broad set of user interests with researchers from all disciplines now leveraging computation and/or big data in interesting and novel ways. This change is not confined to top tier universities, but rather impacts researchers at all institutions of higher learning.  In short, the need to support researchers who span all academic areas and require a diverse set of cyberinfrastructure (CI) has become a key challenge for research centers and IT organizations nationally. Today, scientific discovery is enabled through compute-intensive and data-intensive research that would not be possible without advanced CI.  This project forms a collaborative, state-wide support team, the Kentucky Research Computing team (KyRC), that provides researchers with direct access to expert CI engineers to assist in applying, consulting, and supporting a wide-range of computational systems and research disciplines.  

The goal of KyRC is to serve a broad range of institutions across the state of Kentucky in higher education, smart cities, and community education and training efforts. KyRC provides support to a variety of emerging research areas in need of CI support that heretofore were not part of the computational community. In addition to state-wide support, KyRC collaborates with leading regional and national CI entities to facilitate a community of expertise. By providing access, education, and exposure to advanced CI, KyRC enables research programs to recruit more students (e.g., groups underrepresented in STEM) to computational research while enhancing the training of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs in Kentucky higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In recent years there has been a significant increase in the use of big data to drive research discoveries.  This dependence on big data has been widespread, affecting almost all research domains and application areas.  To support the increasing levels of compute and data-intensive research occurring across institutions of higher learning, there has been a growing need to address both the challenges faced by researchers trying to access and use advanced compute and storage resources in their research, as well as the need to develop the skills and expertise required to support the technologies and systems used to implement these advanced cyberinfrastructure systems. To address these challenges and the need to offer advanced cyberinfrastructure support and service to researchers across the Commonwealth, this project established a cyberteam composed of institutions across the state.


The goal of the Kentucky Research Computing (KyRC) Cyberteam is to support the advanced cyberinfrastructure needs of researchers and educators across the commonwealth via a cooperative collaboration among nine institutions including Eastern Kentucky University (EKU), the Kentucky Community & Technical College System (KCTCS), Kentucky State University (KSU), Morehead State University (MoSU), Murray State University (MuSU), Northern Kentucky University (NKU), the University of Louisville (UofL), Western Kentucky University (WKU), and the University of Kentucky (UKY).  In addition to serving as a state-wide support team for the operation and use of advanced cyberinfrastructure, the KyRC cyberteam avoids the need to replicate systems and support staff across all participating institutions and encourages collaboration and sharing among faculty and staff at the various institutions.


Over the course of the project, we developed a KyRC Cyberteam community consisting of two distinct groups: (1) an Information Technology (IT) Leadership group, and (2) a Computational Research group.  The IT Leadership group consists of the Chief Information Officers from the various KyRC institutions as well as key IT staff supporting research computing and data at those institutions.  The Computational Research group is a community of faculty that includes both researchers and educators interested in big-data and associated computational techniques and spans all KyRC Cyberteam institutions.  The Cyberteam project organizes regular meetings for both groups, including presentations, educational talks, technical talks, and training sessions focused on the specific interests, needs, and challenges raised by group members.  In addition, we support mailing lists for each of the groups to post announcements about upcoming meetings, workshops, training events, and other activities of interest.  In addition, we developed an annual conference called the Commonwealth Computational Summit focused on the needs of computational researchers and educators that has been highly successful.  Recent Summits have focused on the rapidly growing area of AI, providing talks and training tailored for researchers beginning to leverage AI approaches in their work, as well as sessions for educators interested in incorporating AI into their coursework.


We also worked closely with the Kentucky Council on Post-Secondary Education to ensure the state-wide regional network, KyRON, provides the necessary network connectivity for researchers across the state to effectively use the KyRC cyberinfrastructure which included creating an additional 100 Gbps connection to Internet 2 and various national resources.  We also worked with all the KyRC Cyberteam institutions to install a state-wide perfSONAR network with nodes at each of the institutions to monitor and measure the performance of the regional network.


We also continued to expand the computational and storage resources available to KyRC Cyberteam researchers and educators throughout the project.  Since the start of the project, the computational resource capabilities available to researchers have more than tripled, and the storage capabilities have increased by roughly one order of magnitude.  We also developed and deployed federated access capabilities to make it easier for cyberteam members to access the resources and collaborate.


The KyRC Cyberteam also worked with other cyberteam projects around the country to share experiences regarding developing a community and supporting users.  These collaborations ultimately led to the formation of a support track that is providing user support for the NSF ACCESS project.  In short, the KyRC project has successfully developed a research community around the need to grow expertise and enhance knowledge in the area of research computing and data, and plans to continue fostering and developing the cyberteam community going forward.
